Cleveland.Cleveland Recording Company:
Cleveland Recording Company was a historic recording studio in Cleveland, Ohio, which produced many hit records in the 1960s and 1970s by artists such as James Gang and Grand Funk Railroad.


== History ==
Cleveland radio announcer Frederick C. Wolf opened Cleveland's first professional recording studio in 1938 at 1220 Huron Road in the Carnegie Hall building. He founded the studio as a place to record local Slovenian musicians he was featuring on his Sunday morning Czechoslovakian music programs on WGAR. One of the early artists to record with Wolf was Cleveland band leader and future "Polka King," Frankie Yankovic.
